7235 def genr8_bkpts(self, col, nmin=5, tol=1e-12, mask=None): 

7236 r"""Generate list of unique values for one *col* 

7237 

7238 :Call: 

7239 >>> B = db.genr8_bkpts(col, nmin=5, tol=1e-12, mask=None) 

7240 :Inputs: 

7241 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7242 Data container 

7243 *col*: :class:`str` 

7244 Individual lookup variable 

7245 *nmin*: {``5``} | :class:`int` > 0 

7246 Minimum number of data points at one value of a key 

7247 *tol*: {``1e-12``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

7248 Tolerance for values considered to be equal 

7249 *mask*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool` | :class:`int`] 

7250 Mask of which database indices to consider 

7251 :Outputs: 

7252 *B*: :class:`np.ndarray` | :class:`list` 

7253 Unique values of *DBc[col]* with at least *nmin* entries 

7254 :Versions: 

7255 * 2020-05-06 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7256 """ 

7257 # Check type 

7258 if not isinstance(col, typeutils.strlike): 

7259 raise TypeError("Column name is not a string") 

7260 # Check if present 

7261 if col not in self.cols: 

7262 raise KeyError("Lookup column '%s' is not present" % col) 

7263 # Get all values 

7264 V = self.get_values(col, mask) 

7265 # Get data type 

7266 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(col) 

7267 # Check dtype 

7268 if dtype == "str": 

7269 # Get unique values without converting to array 

7270 B = list(set(V)) 

7271 elif dtype.startswith("int"): 

7272 # No need to apply tolerance 

7273 B = np.unique(V) 

7274 else: 

7275 # Get unique values of array 

7276 U = np.unique(V) 

7277 # Initialize filtered value 

7278 B = np.zeros_like(U) 

7279 n = 0 

7280 # Loop through entries 

7281 for v in U: 

7282 # Check if too close to a previous entry 

7283 if (n > 0) and np.min(np.abs(v - B[:n])) <= tol: 

7284 # Close to previous "unique" value 

7285 continue 

7286 # Count entries 

7287 if np.count_nonzero(np.abs(V - v) <= tol) >= nmin: 

7288 # Save the value 

7289 B[n] = v 

7290 # Increase count 

7291 n += 1 

7292 # Trim 

7293 B = B[:n] 

7294 # Output 

7295 return B 

7296 

7297 # Map break points from other key 

7298 def create_bkpts_map(self, cols, scol, tol=1e-12): 

7299 r"""Map break points of one column to one or more others 

7300 

7301 The most common purpose to use this method is to create 

7302 non-ascending break points. One common example is to keep track 

7303 of the dynamic pressure values at each Mach number. These 

7304 dynamic pressures may be unique, but sorting them by dynamic 

7305 pressure is different from the order in which they occur in 

7306 flight. 

7307 

7308 :Call: 

7309 >>> db.create_bkpts_map(cols, scol, tol=1e-12) 

7310 :Inputs: 

7311 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7312 Data container 

7313 *cols*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

7314 Individual lookup variable 

7315 *scol*: :class:`str` 

7316 Name of key to drive map/schedule 

7317 *tol*: {``1e-12``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

7318 Tolerance cutoff (used for *scol*) 

7319 :Outputs: 

7320 *DBc.bkpts*: :class:`dict` 

7321 Dictionary of 1D unique lookup values 

7322 *DBc.bkpts[key]*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

7323 Unique values of *DBc[key]* with at least *nmin* entries 

7324 :Versions: 

7325 * 2018-06-29 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7326 * 2019-12-16 ``@ddalle``: Ported to :mod:`rdbnull` 

7327 * 2020-03-26 ``@ddalle``: Renamed, :func:`map_bkpts` 

7328 """ 

7329 # Check inputs 

7330 if not isinstance(cols, list): 

7331 raise TypeError("Columns input must be a list") 

7332 elif not isinstance(scol, typeutils.strlike): 

7333 raise TypeError("Schedule key must be a string") 

7334 # Get break points 

7335 bkpts = self.__dict__.get("bkpts") 

7336 # Check break points for *scol* 

7337 if bkpts is None: 

7338 raise AttributeError("No 'bkpts' attribute; call get_bkpts()") 

7339 elif scol not in bkpts: 

7340 raise AttributeError("No bkpts for col '%s'" % col) 

7341 # Get data type of *scol* 

7342 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(scol) 

7343 # Check data type 

7344 if not (dtype.startswith("float") or dtype.startswith("int")): 

7345 raise TypeError( 

7346 ("Schedule col '%s' must have either " % scol) + 

7347 ("float or int type (got %s)" % dtype)) 

7348 # Get schedule break points and nominal values 

7349 V0 = self[scol] 

7350 U0 = self.bkpts[scol] 

7351 # Loop through keys 

7352 for col in cols: 

7353 # Check type 

7354 if not isinstance(col, typeutils.strlike): 

7355 raise TypeError("Column name is not a string") 

7356 # Check if present 

7357 if col not in self.cols: 

7358 raise KeyError("Lookup column '%s' is not present" % col) 

7359 # Get data type 

7360 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(col) 

7361 # Check it 

7362 if not (dtype.startswith("float") or dtype.startswith("int")): 

7363 raise TypeError( 

7364 ("Break point col '%s' must have either " % col) + 

7365 ("float or int type (got %s)" % dtype)) 

7366 # Values for *col* 

7367 V = self[col] 

7368 # Initialize break point array for *col* 

7369 U = np.zeros(U0.size, dtype=dtype) 

7370 # Check shape 

7371 if V.size != V0.size: 

7372 raise ValueError( 

7373 ("Col '%s' (%i) has different size " % (col, V.size)) + 

7374 ("from schedule col '%s' (%i)" % (scol, V0.size))) 

7375 # Loop through slice values 

7376 for (j, v0) in enumerate(U0): 

7377 # Find value of slice key matching that parameter 

7378 i = np.where(np.abs(V0 - v0) <= tol)[0][0] 

7379 # Save value of that index from col 

7380 U[j] = V[i] 

7381 # Save break points 

7382 bkpts[col] = U 

7383 

7384 # Schedule break points at slices at other key 

7385 def create_bkpts_schedule(self, cols, scol, nmin=5, tol=1e-12): 

7386 r"""Create lists of unique values at each unique value of *scol* 

7387 

7388 This function creates a break point list of the unique values of 

7389 each *col* in *cols* at each unique value of a "scheduling" 

7390 column *scol*. For example, if a different run matrix of 

7391 *alpha* and *beta* is used at each *mach* number, this function 

7392 creates a list of the unique *alpha* and *beta* values for each 

7393 Mach number in *db.bkpts["mach"]*. 

7394 

7395 :Call: 

7396 >>> db.create_bkpts_schedule(cols, scol) 

7397 :Inputs: 

7398 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7399 Data container 

7400 *cols*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

7401 Individual lookup variable 

7402 *scol*: :class:`str` 

7403 Name of key to drive map/schedule 

7404 *nmin*: {``5``} | :class:`int` > 0 

7405 Minimum number of data points at one value of a key 

7406 *tol*: {``1e-12``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

7407 Tolerance cutoff 

7408 :Outputs: 

7409 *db.bkpts*: :class:`dict` 

7410 Dictionary of unique lookup values 

7411 *db.bkpts[col]*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`np.ndarray`] 

7412 Unique values of *db[col]* at each value of *scol* 

7413 :Versions: 

7414 * 2018-06-29 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7415 * 2019-12-16 ``@ddalle``: Ported to :mod:`rdbnull` 

7416 * 2020-03-26 ``@ddalle``: Renamed, :func:`schedule_bkpts` 

7417 """ 

7418 # Check inputs 

7419 if not isinstance(cols, list): 

7420 raise TypeError("Columns input must be a list") 

7421 elif not isinstance(scol, typeutils.strlike): 

7422 raise TypeError("Schedule key must be a string") 

7423 # Get break points 

7424 bkpts = self.__dict__.get("bkpts") 

7425 # Check break points for *scol* 

7426 if bkpts is None: 

7427 raise AttributeError("No 'bkpts' attribute; call get_bkpts()") 

7428 elif scol not in bkpts: 

7429 raise AttributeError("No bkpts for col '%s'" % col) 

7430 # Get data type of *scol* 

7431 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(scol) 

7432 # Check data type 

7433 if not (dtype.startswith("float") or dtype.startswith("int")): 

7434 raise TypeError( 

7435 ("Schedule col '%s' must have either " % scol) + 

7436 ("float or int type (got %s)" % dtype)) 

7437 # Get schedule break points and nominal values 

7438 V0 = self[scol] 

7439 U0 = self.bkpts[scol] 

7440 # Loop through keys 

7441 for col in cols: 

7442 # Check type 

7443 if not isinstance(col, typeutils.strlike): 

7444 raise TypeError("Column name is not a string") 

7445 # Check if present 

7446 if col not in self.cols: 

7447 raise KeyError("Lookup column '%s' is not present" % col) 

7448 # Get data type 

7449 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(col) 

7450 # Check it 

7451 if not (dtype.startswith("float") or dtype.startswith("int")): 

7452 raise TypeError( 

7453 ("Break point col '%s' must have either " % col) + 

7454 ("float or int type (got %s)" % dtype)) 

7455 # Values for *col* 

7456 V = self[col] 

7457 # Initialize break point array for *col* 

7458 U = np.zeros(U0.size, dtype=dtype) 

7459 # Check shape 

7460 if V.size != V0.size: 

7461 raise ValueError( 

7462 ("Col '%s' (%i) has different size " % (col, V.size)) + 

7463 ("from schedule col '%s' (%i)" % (scol, V0.size))) 

7464 # Initialize scheduled break points 

7465 X = [] 

7466 # Get all values for this key 

7467 V = self[col] 

7468 # Loop through slice values 

7469 for (j, v0) in enumerate(U0): 

7470 # Indices of points in this slice 

7471 I = np.where(np.abs(V0 - v0) <= tol)[0] 

7472 # Check for broken break point 

7473 if I.size == 0: 

7474 # This shouldn't happen 

7475 raise ValueError("No points matching slice at " + 

7476 ("%s = %.2e" % (scol, v0))) 

7477 elif I.size < nmin: 

7478 # No hope of break points at this *scol* value 

7479 X.append(np.zeros(0, dtype=V.dtype)) 

7480 continue 

7481 # Get unique values on the slice 

7482 U = np.unique(V[I]) 

7483 # Initialize filtered value 

7484 B = np.zeros_like(U) 

7485 n = 0 

7486 # Loop through entries 

7487 for v in U: 

7488 # Check if too close to a previous entry 

7489 if (n > 0) and np.min(np.abs(v - B[:n])) <= tol: 

7490 continue 

7491 # Count entries 

7492 if np.count_nonzero(np.abs(V[I] - v) <= tol) >= nmin: 

7493 # Save the value 

7494 B[n] = v 

7495 # Increment count 

7496 n += 1 

7497 # Save break point 

7498 X.append(B[:n]) 

7499 # Save break points 

7500 bkpts[col] = X 

7501 

7502 # --- Breakpoint Lookup --- 

7503 # Find index of break point value 

7504 def get_bkpt_index(self, col, v, tol=1e-8): 

7505 r"""Get interpolation weights for 1D linear interpolation 

7506 

7507 :Call: 

7508 >>> i0, i1, f = db.get_bkpt_index(k, v, tol=1e-8) 

7509 :Inputs: 

7510 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7511 Data container 

7512 *col*: :class:`str` 

7513 Individual lookup variable from *db.bkpts* 

7514 *v*: :class:`float` 

7515 Value at which to lookup 

7516 *tol*: {``1e-8``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

7517 Tolerance for left and right bounds 

7518 :Outputs: 

7519 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7520 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

7521 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7522 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

7523 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

7524 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound 

7525 :Versions: 

7526 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7527 * 2019-12-16 ``@ddalle``: Updated for :mod:`rdbnull` 

7528 """ 

7529 # Extract values 

7530 try: 

7531 # Naive extractions 

7532 V =self.bkpts[col] 

7533 except AttributeError: 

7534 # No break points 

7535 raise AttributeError("No break point dict present") 

7536 except KeyError: 

7537 # Missing key 

7538 raise KeyError( 

7539 "Col '%s' is not present in break point dict" % col) 

7540 # Check type 

7541 if not isinstance(V, np.ndarray): 

7542 # Bad break point array type 

7543 raise TypeError( 

7544 "Break point list for '%s' is not np.ndarray" % col) 

7545 elif V.ndim != 1: 

7546 # Multidmensional array 

7547 raise ValueError( 

7548 ("Cannot perform lookup on %iD array " % V.ndim) + 

7549 ("for column '%s'" % col)) 

7550 elif V.size == 0: 

7551 # No break points 

7552 raise ValueError("Break point array for col '%s' is empty" % col) 

7553 elif V.size == 1: 

7554 # Only one 

7555 raise ValueError( 

7556 "Break point array for col '%s' has only one entry" % col) 

7557 # Output 

7558 return self._bkpt_index(V, v, tol=tol) 

7559 

7560 # Function to get interpolation weights for uq 

7561 def get_bkpt_index_schedule(self, k, v, j): 

7562 """Get weights 1D interpolation of *k* at a slice of master key 

7563 

7564 :Call: 

7565 >>> i0, i1, f = db.get_bkpt_index_schedule(k, v, j) 

7566 :Inputs: 

7567 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7568 Data container 

7569 *k*: :class:`str` 

7570 Name of trajectory key in *FM.bkpts* for lookup 

7571 *v*: :class:`float` 

7572 Value at which to lookup 

7573 *j*: :class:`int` 

7574 Index of master "slice" key, if *k* has scheduled 

7575 break points 

7576 :Outputs: 

7577 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7578 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

7579 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7580 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

7581 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

7582 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound 

7583 :Versions: 

7584 * 2018-04-19 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7585 """ 

7586 # Get potential values 

7587 V = self._scheduled_bkpts(k, j) 

7588 # Lookup within this vector 

7589 return self._bkpt(V, v) 

7590 

7591 # Get break point from vector 

7592 def _bkpt_index(self, V, v, tol=1e-5, col=None): 

7593 r"""Get interpolation weights for 1D interpolation 

7594 

7595 This function tries to find *i0* and *i1* such that *v* is 

7596 between *V[i0]* and *V[i1]*. It assumes the values of *V* are 

7597 unique and ascending (not checked). 

7598 

7599 :Call: 

7600 >>> i0, i1, f = db._bkpt_index(V, v, tol=1e-8) 

7601 :Inputs: 

7602 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7603 Data container 

7604 *V*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

7605 1D array of data values 

7606 *v*: :class:`float` 

7607 Value at which to lookup 

7608 *tol*: {``1e-8``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

7609 Tolerance for left and right bounds 

7610 :Outputs: 

7611 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7612 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

7613 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7614 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

7615 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

7616 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound; 

7617 can be outside 0-1 bound for extrapolation 

7618 :Versions: 

7619 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7620 * 2019-12-16 ``@ddalle``: Version 2.0; for :mod:`rdbnull` 

7621 """ 

7622 # Get length 

7623 n = V.size 

7624 # Get min/max 

7625 vmin = np.min(V) 

7626 vmax = np.max(V) 

7627 # Check for extrapolation cases 

7628 if n == 1: 

7629 # Only one point 

7630 return 0, None, 1.0 

7631 if v < vmin - tol*(vmax-vmin): 

7632 # Extrapolation left 

7633 return None, 0, (v-V[0])/(V[1]-V[0]) 

7634 if v > vmax + tol*(vmax-vmin): 

7635 # Extrapolation right 

7636 return n-1, None, (v-V[-2])/(V[-1]-V[-2]) 

7637 # Otherwise, count up values below 

7638 i0 = np.sum(V[:-1] <= v) - 1 

7639 i1 = i0 + 1 

7640 # Progress fraction 

7641 f = (v - V[i0]) / (V[i1] - V[i0]) 

7642 # Output 

7643 return i0, i1, f 

7644 

7645 # Get a break point, with error checking 

7646 def get_bkpt(self, col, *I): 

7647 r"""Extract a breakpoint by index, with error checking 

7648 

7649 :Call: 

7650 >>> v = db.get_bkpt(col, *I) 

7651 >>> v = db.get_bkpt(col) 

7652 >>> v = db.get_bkpt(col, i) 

7653 >>> v = db.get_bkpt(col, i, j) 

7654 >>> v = db.get_bkpt(col, i, j, ...) 

7655 :Inputs: 

7656 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7657 Data container 

7658 *col*: :class:`str` 

7659 Individual lookup variable from *db.bkpts* 

7660 *I*: :class:`tuple` 

7661 Tuple of lookup indices 

7662 *i*: :class:`int` 

7663 (Optional) first break point list index 

7664 *j*: :class:`int` 

7665 (Optional) second break point list index 

7666 :Outputs: 

7667 *v*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

7668 Break point or array of break points 

7669 :Versions: 

7670 * 2018-12-31 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7671 * 2019-12-16 ``@ddalle``: Updated for :mod:`rdbnull` 

7672 """ 

7673 # Get the break points 

7674 try: 

7675 v = self.bkpts[col] 

7676 except AttributeError: 

7677 # No radial basis functions at all 

7678 raise AttributeError("No break points found") 

7679 except KeyError: 

7680 # No RBF for this coefficient 

7681 raise KeyError("No break points for col '%s'" % col) 

7682 # Number of indices given 

7683 nd = len(I) 

7684 # Loop through indices 

7685 for n, i in enumerate(I): 

7686 # Try to extract 

7687 try: 

7688 # Get the *ith* list entry 

7689 v = v[i] 

7690 except (IndexError, TypeError): 

7691 # Reached scalar too soon 

7692 raise TypeError( 

7693 ("Breakpoints for '%s':\n" % col) + 

7694 ("Expecting %i-dimensional " % nd) + 

7695 ("array but found %i-dim" % n)) 

7696 # Output 

7697 return v 

7698 

7699 # Get all break points 

7700 def _scheduled_bkpts(self, col, j): 

7701 """Get list of break points for key *col* at schedule *j* 

7702 

7703 :Call: 

7704 >>> i0, i1, f = db._scheduled_bkpts(col, j) 

7705 :Inputs: 

7706 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7707 Data container 

7708 *col*: :class:`str` 

7709 Individual lookup variable from *db.bkpts* 

7710 *j*: :class:`int` 

7711 Index of master "slice" key, if *col* has scheduled 

7712 break points 

7713 :Outputs: 

7714 *i0*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7715 Lower bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation below 

7716 *i1*: ``None`` | :class:`int` 

7717 Upper bound index, if ``None``, extrapolation above 

7718 *f*: 0 <= :class:`float` <= 1 

7719 Lookup fraction, ``1.0`` if *v* is equal to upper bound 

7720 :Versions: 

7721 * 2018-12-30 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7722 * 2019-12-16 ``@ddalle``: Updated for :mod:`rdbnull` 

7723 """ 

7724 # Get the break points 

7725 try: 

7726 V = self.bkpts[col] 

7727 except AttributeError: 

7728 # No radial basis functions at all 

7729 raise AttributeError("No break points found") 

7730 except KeyError: 

7731 # No RBF for this coefficient 

7732 raise KeyError("No break points for col '%s'" % col) 

7733 # Get length 

7734 n = len(V) 

7735 # Size check 

7736 if n == 0: 

7737 raise ValueError("Empty break point array for col '%s'" % col) 

7738 # Check first key for array 

7739 if isinstance(V[0], (np.ndarray, list)): 

7740 # Get break points for this slice 

7741 V = V[j] 

7742 # Reset size 

7743 n = V.size 

7744 # Recheck size 

7745 if n == 0: 

7746 raise ValueError( 

7747 ("Empty break point array for col '%s' " % col) + 

7748 ("at slice %i" % j)) 

7749 # Output 

7750 return V 

7751 

7752 # --- Full Factorial --- 

7753 # Fill out a slice matrix 

7754 def get_fullfactorial(self, scol=None, cols=None): 

7755 r"""Create full-factorial matrix of values in break points 

7756 

7757 This allows some of the break points cols to be scheduled, i.e. 

7758 there are different matrices of *cols* for each separate value 

7759 of *scol*. 

7760 

7761 :Call: 

7762 >>> X, slices = db.get_fullfactorial(scol=None, cols=None) 

7763 :Inputs: 

7764 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7765 Data container 

7766 *scol*: {``None``} | :class:`str` | :class:`list` 

7767 Optional name of slicing col(s) 

7768 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

7769 List of (ordered) input keys, default is from *DBc.bkpts* 

7770 :Outputs: 

7771 *X*: :class:`dict` 

7772 Dictionary of full-factorial matrix 

7773 *slices*: :class:`dict` (:class:`ndarray`) 

7774 Array of slice values for each col in *scol* 

7775 :Versions: 

7776 * 2018-11-16 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7777 """ 

7778 # --- Slice col Checks --- 

7779 # Check for list or string 

7780 if isinstance(scol, list): 

7781 # Get additional slice keys 

7782 subcols = scol[1:] 

7783 # Single slice key 

7784 maincol = scol[0] 

7785 elif scol is None: 

7786 # No slices at all 

7787 subcols = [] 

7788 maincol = None 

7789 elif typeutils.isstr(scol): 

7790 # No additional slice keys 

7791 subcols = [] 

7792 maincol = scol 

7793 # List of slice keys 

7794 scol = [scol] 

7795 else: 

7796 raise TypeError("Slicing column must be 'list' or 'str'") 

7797 # --- col Checks --- 

7798 # Get break points 

7799 bkpts = self.__dict__.get("bkpts", {}) 

7800 # Default col list 

7801 if cols is None: 

7802 # Default list 

7803 cols = [] 

7804 # Loop through breakpoints 

7805 for (col, V) in bkpts.items(): 

7806 # Check if *V* is an array 

7807 if not isinstance(V, np.ndarray): 

7808 # Non-array 

7809 continue 

7810 elif V.size == 0: 

7811 # Empty break points 

7812 continue 

7813 elif V.ndim != 1: 

7814 # What? ND array 

7815 continue 

7816 elif not isinstance(V[0], float): 

7817 # Not a simple number 

7818 continue 

7819 # If reaching this point, usable column 

7820 cols.append(col) 

7821 else: 

7822 # Loop through breakpoints 

7823 for col in cols: 

7824 # Get break points 

7825 V = bkpts.get(col) 

7826 # Check if *V* is an array 

7827 if V is None: 

7828 raise KeyError("No breakpoints for col '%s'" % col) 

7829 elif col in subcols and isinstance(V, (list, np.ndarray)): 

7830 # Special case for secondary slice col 

7831 continue 

7832 elif not isinstance(V, np.ndarray): 

7833 # Non-array 

7834 raise TypeError( 

7835 "Breakpoints for col '%s' is not array" % col) 

7836 elif V.size == 0: 

7837 # Empty break points 

7838 raise IndexError( 

7839 "Breakpoints for col '%s' is empty" % col) 

7840 elif V.ndim != 1: 

7841 # What? ND array 

7842 raise IndexError( 

7843 "Breakpoints for col '%s' is not 1D" % col) 

7844 elif not isinstance(V[0], (float, int, complex)): 

7845 # Not a simple number 

7846 raise TypeError( 

7847 "Non-numeric breakpoints for col '%s'" % col) 

7848 # Make a copy 

7849 cols = list(cols) 

7850 # Eliminate *skey* if in key list 

7851 if maincol in cols: 

7852 cols.remove(maincol) 

7853 # --- Slice Init --- 

7854 # Initialize slice dictionary 

7855 slices = {} 

7856 # Initialize main slice values 

7857 if maincol is not None: 

7858 slices[maincol] = np.zeros(0) 

7859 # Loop through slice keys 

7860 for col in subcols: 

7861 # Initialize slice 

7862 slices[col] = np.zeros(0) 

7863 # Check if listed in "cols" 

7864 if col not in cols: 

7865 cols.insert(0, col) 

7866 # Number of columns 

7867 ncol = len(cols) 

7868 # Number of slice keys 

7869 if scol is None: 

7870 # No slices 

7871 nscol = 0 

7872 else: 

7873 # Get length 

7874 nscol = len(scol) 

7875 # --- Matrix Init --- 

7876 # Initialize dictionary of full-factorial matrix 

7877 X = {} 

7878 # Slice check 

7879 if maincol is None: 

7880 # No values to check 

7881 M = np.zeros(1) 

7882 else: 

7883 # Get breakpoints for specified value 

7884 M = bkpts[maincol] 

7885 # Also keep track of slice key values 

7886 X[maincol] = np.zeros(0) 

7887 # Initialize values 

7888 for col in cols: 

7889 X[col] = np.zeros(0) 

7890 # --- Main Slice Loop --- 

7891 # Loop through slice values 

7892 for (im, m) in enumerate(M): 

7893 # Initialize matrix for this slice 

7894 Xm = {} 

7895 # Initialize slice values for this slice 

7896 Xs = {} 

7897 # Set slice values 

7898 if maincol: 

7899 # Main slice col has value of main col 

7900 Xs[maincol] = np.array([m]) 

7901 # Copy values 

7902 for col in cols: 

7903 # Get values 

7904 Vm = bkpts[col] 

7905 # Get first entry for type checks 

7906 v0 = bkpts[col][0] 

7907 # Check if it's a scheduled key; will be an array 

7908 if isinstance(v0, (list, np.ndarray)): 

7909 # Get break points for this slice key value 

7910 Vm = Vm[im] 

7911 # Save the values 

7912 Xm[col] = Vm 

7913 # Save slice if appropriate 

7914 if col in subcols: 

7915 Xs[col] = Vm 

7916 # Loop through break point keys to create full-factorial inputs 

7917 for i in range(1, ncol): 

7918 # Name of first key 

7919 col1 = cols[i] 

7920 # Loop through keys 0 to *i*-1 

7921 for j in range(i): 

7922 # Name of second key 

7923 col2 = cols[j] 

7924 # Create N+1 dimensional interpolation 

7925 x1, x2 = np.meshgrid(Xm[col1], Xm[col2]) 

7926 # Flatten 

7927 Xm[col2] = x2.flatten() 

7928 # Save first key if *j* ix 0 

7929 if j == i-1: 

7930 Xm[col1] = x1.flatten() 

7931 # Loop through slice keys to create full-factorial inputs 

7932 for i in range(1, nscol): 

7933 # Name of first key 

7934 col1 = scol[i] 

7935 # Loop through keys 0 to *i*-1 

7936 for j in range(i): 

7937 # Name of second key 

7938 col2 = scol[j] 

7939 # Create N+1 dimensional interpolation 

7940 x1, x2 = np.meshgrid(Xs[col1], Xs[col2]) 

7941 # Flatten 

7942 Xs[col2] = x2.flatten() 

7943 # Save first key if *j* ix 0 

7944 if j == i-1: 

7945 Xs[col1] = x1.flatten() 

7946 # Save values 

7947 for col in cols: 

7948 X[col] = np.hstack((X[col], Xm[col])) 

7949 # Process slices 

7950 if maincol is not None: 

7951 # Append to *scol* matrix 

7952 X[maincol] = np.hstack( 

7953 (X[maincol], m*np.ones_like(Xm[col]))) 

7954 # Save slice full-factorial matrix 

7955 for col in scol: 

7956 slices[col] = np.hstack((slices[col], Xs[col])) 

7957 # Output 

7958 return X, slices 

7959 # > 

7960 

7961 # ==================== 

7962 # Interpolation Tools 

7963 # ==================== 

7964 # < 

7965 # --- RBF construction --- 

7966 # Regularization 

7967 def create_global_rbfs(self, cols, args, I=None, **kw): 

7968 r"""Create global radial basis functions for one or more columns 

7969 

7970 :Call: 

7971 >>> db.create_global_rbfs(cols, args, I=None) 

7972 :Inputs: 

7973 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

7974 Database with scalar output functions 

7975 *cols*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

7976 List of columns to create RBFs for 

7977 *args*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

7978 List of (ordered) input keys, default is from *db.bkpts* 

7979 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

7980 Indices of cases to include in RBF (default is all) 

7981 *function*: {``"cubic"``} | :class:`str` 

7982 Radial basis function type 

7983 *smooth*: {``0.0``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

7984 Smoothing factor, ``0.0`` for exact interpolation 

7985 :Effects: 

7986 *db.rbf[col]*: :class:`scipy.interpolate.rbf.Rbf` 

7987 Radial basis function for each *col* in *cols* 

7988 :Versions: 

7989 * 2019-01-01 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

7990 * 2019-12-17 ``@ddalle``: Ported from :mod:`tnakit` 

7991 * 2020-02-22 ``@ddalle``: Utilize :func:`create_rbf` 

7992 """ 

7993 # Check for module 

7994 if scirbf is None: 

7995 raise ImportError("No scipy.interpolate.rbf module") 

7996 # Create *rbf* attribute if needed 

7997 rbf = self.__dict__.setdefault("rbf", {}) 

7998 # Loop through coefficients 

7999 for col in cols: 

8000 # Eval arguments for status update 

8001 txt = str(tuple(args)).replace(" ", "") 

8002 # Trim if too long 

8003 if len(txt) > 50: 

8004 txt = txt[:45] + "...)" 

8005 # Status update line 

8006 txt = "Creating RBF for %s%s" % (col, txt) 

8007 sys.stdout.write("%-72s\r" % txt) 

8008 sys.stdout.flush() 

8009 # Create a single RBF 

8010 rbf[col] = self.genr8_rbf(col, args, I=I, **kw) 

8011 # Clean up the prompt 

8012 sys.stdout.write("%72s\r" % "") 

8013 sys.stdout.flush() 

8014 

8015 # RBFs on slices 

8016 def create_slice_rbfs(self, cols, args, I=None, **kw): 

8017 r"""Create radial basis functions for each slice of *args[0]* 

8018 

8019 The first entry in *args* is interpreted as a "slice" key; RBFs 

8020 will be constructed at constant values of *args[0]*. 

8021 

8022 :Call: 

8023 >>> db.create_slice_rbfs(coeffs, args, I=None) 

8024 :Inputs: 

8025 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8026 Database with scalar output functions 

8027 *cols*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8028 List of columns to create RBFs for 

8029 *args*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8030 List of (ordered) input keys, default is from *db.bkpts* 

8031 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

8032 Indices of cases to include in RBF (default is all) 

8033 *function*: {``"cubic"``} | :class:`str` 

8034 Radial basis function type 

8035 *smooth*: {``0.0``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

8036 Smoothing factor, ``0.0`` for exact interpolation 

8037 :Effects: 

8038 *db.rbf[col]*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`scirbf.Rbf`] 

8039 List of RBFs at each slice for each *col* in *cols* 

8040 :Versions: 

8041 * 2019-01-01 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8042 * 2019-12-17 ``@ddalle``: Ported from :mod:`tnakit` 

8043 """ 

8044 # Check for module 

8045 if scirbf is None: 

8046 raise ImportError("No scipy.interpolate.rbf module") 

8047 # Create *rbf* attribute if needed 

8048 self.__dict__.setdefault("rbf", {}) 

8049 # RBF options 

8050 func = kw.get("function", "cubic") 

8051 smooth = kw.get("smooth", 0.0) 

8052 # Name of slice key 

8053 skey = args[0] 

8054 # Tolerances 

8055 tols = kw.get("tols", {}) 

8056 # Tolerance for slice key 

8057 tol = kw.get("tol", tols.get(skey, 1e-6)) 

8058 # Default indices 

8059 if I is None: 

8060 # Size of database 

8061 n = len(self[skey]) 

8062 # All the indices 

8063 I = np.arange(n) 

8064 # Get break points for slice key 

8065 B = self.bkpts[skey] 

8066 # Number of slices 

8067 nslice = len(B) 

8068 # Initialize the RBFs 

8069 for col in cols: 

8070 self.rbf[col] = [] 

8071 # Loop through slices 

8072 for b in B: 

8073 # Get slice constraints 

8074 qj = np.abs(self[skey][I] - b) <= tol 

8075 # Select slice and add to list 

8076 J = I[qj] 

8077 # Create tuple of input points 

8078 V = tuple(self[k][J] for k in args[1:]) 

8079 # Create a string for slice coordinate and remaining args 

8080 arg_string_list = ["%s=%g" % (skey,b)] 

8081 arg_string_list += [str(k) for k in args[1:]] 

8082 # Joint list with commas 

8083 arg_string = "(" + (",".join(arg_string_list)) + ")" 

8084 # Loop through coefficients 

8085 for col in cols: 

8086 # Status update 

8087 txt = "Creating RBF for %s%s" % (col, arg_string) 

8088 sys.stdout.write("%-72s\r" % txt[:72]) 

8089 sys.stdout.flush() 

8090 # Append reference values to input tuple 

8091 Z = V + (self[col][J],) 

8092 # Create a single RBF 

8093 f = scirbf.Rbf(*Z, function=func, smooth=smooth) 

8094 # Save it 

8095 self.rbf[col].append(f) 

8096 # Save break points for slice key 

8097 self.bkpts[skey] = B 

8098 # Save break points for other args 

8099 self.create_bkpts_schedule(args[1:], skey, nmin=1) 

8100 # Clean up the prompt 

8101 sys.stdout.write("%72s\r" % "") 

8102 sys.stdout.flush() 

8103 

8104 # Individual RBF generator 

8105 def genr8_rbf(self, col, args, I=None, **kw): 

8106 r"""Create global radial basis functions for one or more columns 

8107 

8108 :Call: 

8109 >>> rbf = db.genr8_rbf(col, args, I=None) 

8110 :Inputs: 

8111 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8112 Database with scalar output functions 

8113 *col*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8114 Data column to create RBF for 

8115 *args*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8116 List of (ordered) input cols 

8117 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

8118 Indices of cases to include in RBF (default is all) 

8119 *function*: {``"cubic"``} | :class:`str` 

8120 Radial basis function type 

8121 *smooth*: {``0.0``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

8122 Smoothing factor, ``0.0`` for exact interpolation 

8123 :Output: 

8124 *rbf*: :class:`scipy.interpolate.rbf.Rbf` 

8125 Radial basis function for *col* 

8126 :Versions: 

8127 * 2019-01-01 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8128 * 2019-12-17 ``@ddalle``: Ported from :mod:`tnakit` 

8129 * 2020-02-22 ``@ddalle``: Single-*col* version 

8130 * 2020-03-06 ``@ddalle``: Name from :funC:`create_rbf` 

8131 """ 

8132 # Check for module 

8133 if scirbf is None: 

8134 raise ImportError("No scipy.interpolate.rbf module") 

8135 # RBF options 

8136 func = kw.get("function", "cubic") 

8137 smooth = kw.get("smooth", 0.0) 

8138 # Create tuple of input points 

8139 V = tuple(self.get_values(arg, I) for arg in args) 

8140 # Append reference values to input tuple 

8141 Z = V + (self.get_values(col, I),) 

8142 # Create a single RBF 

8143 rbf = scirbf.Rbf(*Z, function=func, smooth=smooth) 

8144 # Output 

8145 return rbf 

8146 

8147 # --- Griddata --- 

8148 # Individual griddata generator 

8149 def genr8_griddata_weights(self, args, *a, **kw): 

8150 r"""Generate interpolation weights for :func:`griddata` 

8151 

8152 :Call: 

8153 >>> W = db.genr8_griddata_weights(arg, *a, **kw) 

8154 :Inputs: 

8155 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8156 Data container 

8157 *a*: :class:`tuple`\ [:class:`np.ndarray`] 

8158 Test values at which to interpolate 

8159 *mask*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool`] 

8160 Mask of which database indices to consider 

8161 *I*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

8162 Database indices to consider 

8163 *method*: {``"linear"``} | ``"cubic"`` | ``"nearest"`` 

8164 Interpolation method; ``"cubic"`` only for 1D or 2D 

8165 *rescale*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

8166 Rescale input points to unit cube before interpolation 

8167 :Outputs: 

8168 *W*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

8169 Interpolation weights; same size as test points *a* 

8170 :Versions: 

8171 * 2020-03-10 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8172 """ 

8173 # Check for module 

8174 if sciint is None: 

8175 raise ImportError("No scipy.interpolate module") 

8176 # Ensure list (len=2) 

8177 if not isinstance(args, list): 

8178 raise TypeError("Args must be a list, got '%s'" % type(args)) 

8179 elif len(args) == 0: 

8180 raise ValueError("Arg list cannot be empty") 

8181 # Number of args 

8182 narg = len(args) 

8183 # Check args 

8184 for (j, arg) in enumerate(args): 

8185 # Check string 

8186 if not typeutils.isstr(arg): 

8187 raise TypeError("Arg %i is not a string" % j) 

8188 # Get method 

8189 method = kw.get("method", "linear") 

8190 # Other :func:`griddata` options 

8191 rescale = kw.get("rescale", False) 

8192 # Check it 

8193 if method not in ["linear", "cubic", "nearest"]: 

8194 # Invalid method 

8195 raise ValueError("'method' must be either 'linear' or 'cubic'") 

8196 # Check consistency 

8197 if (method == "cubic") and (narg > 2): 

8198 raise ValueError( 

8199 "'cubic' method is for at most 2 args (got %i)" % narg) 

8200 # Number of positional inputs 

8201 na = len(a) 

8202 # Check values 

8203 if na < narg: 

8204 raise TypeError( 

8205 "At least %i positional args required (got %i)" % (narg, na)) 

8206 elif na > 3: 

8207 raise TypeError( 

8208 "At most %i positional args allowed (got %i)" 

8209 % (narg + 1, na)) 

8210 # Get indices 

8211 if na > narg: 

8212 # Initialize with third arg 

8213 I = a[narg] 

8214 else: 

8215 # Leave blank for Now 

8216 I = None 

8217 # Get *I* from kwargs 

8218 mask = kw.get("I", kw.get("mask", None)) 

8219 # Prepare mask 

8220 I = self.prep_mask(mask, args[0]) 

8221 # Get values of args from database 

8222 x = np.vstack(tuple([self.get_values(arg, I)] for arg in args)).T 

8223 # Get output values 

8224 y = np.vstack(tuple([ai] for ai in a[:narg])).T 

8225 # Length of input and output 

8226 n = x.shape[0] 

8227 nout = len(a[0]) 

8228 # Initialize weights 

8229 W = np.zeros((nout, n)) 

8230 # Loop through evaluation points 

8231 for k in range(n): 

8232 # Artificial values 

8233 kmode = np.eye(n)[k] 

8234 # Calculate scattered interpolation weights 

8235 W1 = sciint.griddata(x, kmode, y, method, rescale=rescale) 

8236 W2 = sciint.griddata(x, kmode, y, "nearest", rescale=rescale) 

8237 # Find any NaNs from extrapolation 

8238 K = np.isnan(W1) 

8239 # Replace NaNs with nearest value 

8240 W1[K] = W2[K] 

8241 # Save weights 

8242 W[:,k] = W1 

8243 # Output 

8244 return W 

8245 # > 

8246 

8247 # ================== 

8248 # Filtering 

8249 # ================== 

8250 # < 

8251 # --- Repeats --- 

8252 # Remove repeats 

8253 def filter_repeats(self, args, cols=None, **kw): 

8254 r"""Remove duplicate points or close neighbors 

8255 

8256 :Call: 

8257 >>> db.filter_repeats(args, cols=None, **kw) 

8258 :Inputs: 

8259 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8260 Data container 

8261 *args*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8262 List of columns names to match 

8263 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8264 Columns to filter (default is all *db.cols* with correct 

8265 size and not in *args* and :class:`float` type) 

8266 *mask*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool` | :class:`int`] 

8267 Subset of *db* to consider 

8268 *function*: {``"mean"``} | **callable** 

8269 Function to use for filtering 

8270 *translators*: :class:`dict`\ [:class:`str`] 

8271 Alternate names; *col* -> *trans[col]* 

8272 *prefix*: :class:`str` | :class:`dict` 

8273 Universal prefix or *col*-specific prefixes 

8274 *suffix*: :class:`str` | :class:`dict` 

8275 Universal suffix or *col*-specific suffixes 

8276 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

8277 Additional values to use for evaluation in :func:`find` 

8278 :Versions: 

8279 * 2020-05-05 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8280 """ 

8281 # --- Column Lists --- 

8282 # Check types 

8283 if not isinstance(args, list): 

8284 raise TypeError( 

8285 "Invalid type '%s' for args, must be 'list'" % type(args)) 

8286 elif len(args) < 1: 

8287 raise ValueError("Arg list is empty") 

8288 # Check types of *args* entries 

8289 for j, arg in enumerate(args): 

8290 # Make sure it's a string 

8291 if not typeutils.isstr(arg): 

8292 raise TypeError( 

8293 "Arg %i has invalid type '%s', must be 'str'" 

8294 % (j, type(arg))) 

8295 # Get first arg 

8296 arg0 = args[0] 

8297 # Get count 

8298 n0 = len(self.get_all_values(arg0)) 

8299 # Process columns 

8300 if cols is None: 

8301 # Initialize list 

8302 cols = [] 

8303 # Loop through columns 

8304 for col in self.cols: 

8305 # Check if an *arg* 

8306 if col in args: 

8307 continue 

8308 # Get data type 

8309 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(col) 

8310 # Check datatype 

8311 if dtype is None or not dtype.startswith("float"): 

8312 continue 

8313 # Get dimension 

8314 ndim = self.get_col_prop(col, "Dimension") 

8315 # Filter it 

8316 if ndim is None or ndim != 1: 

8317 continue 

8318 # Check size 

8319 if self.get_all_values(col).size != n0: 

8320 continue 

8321 # Otherwise, use this column 

8322 cols.append(col) 

8323 # --- Filtering Function --- 

8324 # Get filtering function 

8325 func = kw.get("func", "mean") 

8326 # Filter it 

8327 if func == "mean": 

8328 # Take mean of data points 

8329 fn = np.mean 

8330 elif callable(func): 

8331 # Function specified directly 

8332 fn = func 

8333 else: 

8334 # Bad type 

8335 raise TypeError("Filtering function not callable") 

8336 # --- Options --- 

8337 # Get translators 

8338 trans = kw.pop("translators", {}) 

8339 prefix = kw.pop("prefix", None) 

8340 suffix = kw.pop("suffix", None) 

8341 # Overall mask 

8342 mask = kw.get("mask") 

8343 # Translator args 

8344 tr_args = (trans, prefix, suffix) 

8345 # Get overall tolerances 

8346 tol = kw.get("tol", 1e-8) 

8347 # Get tolerances for specific *args* 

8348 tols = kw.get("tols", {}) 

8349 # --- Data --- 

8350 # Divide into sweeps 

8351 sweeps = self.genr8_sweeps(args, **kw) 

8352 # Number of output points 

8353 nx = len(sweeps) 

8354 # Check for trivial filtering 

8355 nmaxsweep = np.max(np.array([sweep.size for sweep in sweeps])) 

8356 # Loop through *cols* first b/c original *arg* values 

8357 # may affect filtering of *cols* 

8358 for col in cols: 

8359 # Translate column name 

8360 colreg = self._translate_colname(col, *tr_args) 

8361 # Check for trivial case 

8362 if nmaxsweep == 1: 

8363 # Get existing data 

8364 V = self.get_values(col, mask) 

8365 else: 

8366 # Get data type 

8367 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(col) 

8368 # Initialize data 

8369 V = np.zeros(nx, dtype=dtype) 

8370 # Loop through sweeps 

8371 for j, sweep in enumerate(sweeps): 

8372 # Get values for these points 

8373 v = self.get_values(col, sweep) 

8374 # Filter 

8375 V[j] = fn(v) 

8376 # Check if new column 

8377 if col != colreg: 

8378 # Save new column 

8379 self.save_col(colreg, V) 

8380 # Get previous definition 

8381 defn = self.get_defn(col) 

8382 # Save a copy 

8383 self.defns[colreg] = self._defncls(_warnmode=0, **defn) 

8384 else: 

8385 # Save new data in place of old data 

8386 self[col] = V 

8387 # Loop through *args* 

8388 for arg in args: 

8389 # Translate column name 

8390 argreg = self._translate_colname(arg, *tr_args) 

8391 # Check for trivial case 

8392 if nmaxsweep == 1: 

8393 # Get existing data 

8394 V = self.get_values(arg, mask) 

8395 else: 

8396 # Get data type 

8397 dtype = self.get_col_dtype(arg) 

8398 # Initialize data 

8399 V = np.zeros(nx, dtype=dtype) 

8400 # Loop through sweeps 

8401 for j, sweep in enumerate(sweeps): 

8402 # Get values for these points 

8403 v = self.get_values(arg, sweep) 

8404 # Filter 

8405 V[j] = fn(v) 

8406 # Check if new column 

8407 if arg != argreg: 

8408 # Save new column 

8409 self.save_col(argreg, V) 

8410 # Get previous definition 

8411 defn = self.get_defn(arg) 

8412 # Save a copy 

8413 self.defns[argreg] = self._defncls(_warnmode=0, **defn) 

8414 else: 

8415 # Save new data in place of old data 

8416 self[arg] = V 

8417 

8418 # Find duplicates 

8419 def find_repeats(self, cols, **kw): 

8420 r"""Find repeats based on list of columns 

8421 

8422 :Call: 

8423 >>> repeats = db.find_repeats(cols, **kw) 

8424 :Inputs: 

8425 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8426 Data container 

8427 *cols*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8428 List of columns names to match 

8429 *mask*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool` | :class:`int`] 

8430 Subset of *db* to consider 

8431 *tol*: {``1e-4``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

8432 Default tolerance for all *args* 

8433 *tols*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict`\ [:class:`float` >= 0] 

8434 Dictionary of tolerances specific to arguments 

8435 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

8436 Additional values to use during evaluation 

8437 :Outputs: 

8438 *repeats*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`np.ndarray`] 

8439 List of *db* indices of repeats; each *repeat* in 

8440 *repeats* is an index of a case that matches for each 

8441 *col* in *cols* 

8442 :Versions: 

8443 * 2021-09-10 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8444 """ 

8445 # Set (force) option for db.find() 

8446 kw["mapped"] = True 

8447 # Get values for each *col* 

8448 x = [self.get_all_values(col) for col in cols] 

8449 # Search for duplicates 

8450 Imap, _ = self.find(cols, *x, **kw) 

8451 # Create set of first index of repeat 

8452 anchors = set() 

8453 # Initialize repeats 

8454 repeats = [] 

8455 # Loop through *Imap* entries 

8456 for imap in Imap: 

8457 # Check if multiple 

8458 if imap.size <= 1: 

8459 continue 

8460 # Check if already anchored 

8461 if imap[0] in anchors: 

8462 continue 

8463 # Save repeate 

8464 repeats.append(imap) 

8465 # Save anchor 

8466 anchors.add(imap[0]) 

8467 # Output 

8468 return repeats 

8469 # > 

8470 

8471 # ================== 

8472 # Data 

8473 # ================== 

8474 # < 

8475 # --- Save/Add --- 

8476 # --- Sort --- 

8477 # Sort by list of columns 

8478 def sort(self, cols=None): 

8479 r"""Sort (ascending) using list of *cols* 

8480 

8481 :Call: 

8482 >>> db.sort(cols=None) 

8483 :Inputs: 

8484 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8485 Data interface with response mechanisms 

8486 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8487 List of columns on which t sort, with highest sort 

8488 priority to the first *col*, later *cols* used as 

8489 tie-breakers 

8490 :Versions: 

8491 * 2021-09-17 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8492 """ 

8493 # Default columns 

8494 if cols is None: 

8495 cols = list(self.cols) 

8496 # First column 

8497 col0 = cols[0] 

8498 # Get value 

8499 v0 = self.get_all_values(col0) 

8500 # Size 

8501 n0 = len(v0) 

8502 # Get sorting order 

8503 I = self.argsort(cols) 

8504 # Loop through all columns 

8505 for col in self.cols: 

8506 # Get value 

8507 v = self.get_all_values(col) 

8508 # Check length 

8509 if len(v) != n0: 

8510 continue 

8511 # Check type 

8512 if isinstance(v, list): 

8513 # Use a generator to reorder a list 

8514 v = [v[i] for i in I] 

8515 elif isinstance(v, np.ndarray): 

8516 # Check dimension 

8517 if v.ndim == 0: 

8518 # No sortable data 

8519 continue 

8520 else: 

8521 # Sort on first axis 

8522 v = v[I] 

8523 # Save sorted values 

8524 self[col] = v 

8525 

8526 # Sort by list of columns (get order) 

8527 def argsort(self, cols=None): 

8528 r"""Get (ascending) sort order using list of *cols* 

8529 

8530 :Call: 

8531 >>> I = db.argsort(cols=None) 

8532 :Inputs: 

8533 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8534 Data interface with response mechanisms 

8535 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8536 List of columns on which t sort, with highest sort 

8537 priority to the first *col*, later *cols* used as 

8538 tie-breakers 

8539 :Outputs: 

8540 *I*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

8541 Ordering such that *db[cols[0]][I]* is ascending, etc. 

8542 :Versions: 

8543 * 2021-09-17 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8544 """ 

8545 # Default columns 

8546 if cols is None: 

8547 cols = list(self.cols) 

8548 # First column 

8549 col0 = cols[0] 

8550 # Get value 

8551 v0 = self.get_all_values(col0) 

8552 # Size 

8553 n0 = len(v0) 

8554 # Start args to :func:`np.lexsort` 

8555 sort_args = [] 

8556 # Loop through columns 

8557 for col in cols: 

8558 # Get value 

8559 v = self.get_all_values(col) 

8560 # Check length 

8561 if len(v) != n0: 

8562 # Can't sort this arg 

8563 continue 

8564 # Check for 2D array 

8565 if isinstance(v, np.ndarray) and v.ndim != 1: 

8566 # Unable to sort matrices 

8567 continue 

8568 # Prepend to list (lexsort() prioritizes last arg) 

8569 sort_args.insert(0, v) 

8570 # Sort 

8571 return np.lexsort(sort_args) 

8572 

8573 # --- Copy/Link --- 

8574 # Append data 

8575 def append_data(self, dbsrc, cols=None, **kw): 

8576 r"""Save one or more cols from another database 

8577 

8578 .. note:: 

8579 

8580 This is the same as :func:`link_data` but with *append* 

8581 defaulting to ``True``. 

8582 

8583 :Call: 

8584 >>> db.append_data(dbsrc, cols=None) 

8585 :Inputs: 

8586 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8587 Data container 

8588 *dbsrc*: :class:`dict` 

8589 Additional data container, not required to be a datakit 

8590 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8591 List of columns to link (or *dbsrc.cols*) 

8592 *append*: {``True``} | ``False`` 

8593 Option to append data (or replace it) 

8594 *prefix*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

8595 Prefix applied to *dbsrc* col when saved in *db* 

8596 *suffix*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

8597 Prefix applied to *dbsrc* col when saved in *db* 

8598 :Effects: 

8599 *db.cols*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8600 Appends each *col* in *cols* where not present 

8601 *db[col]*: *dbsrc[col]* 

8602 Reference to *dbsrc* data for each *col* 

8603 :Versions: 

8604 * 2021-09-10 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8605 """ 

8606 # Set *append* to ``True`` 

8607 kw.setdefault("append", True) 

8608 # Link data 

8609 self.link_data(dbsrc, cols, **kw) 

8610 

8611 # Link data 

8612 def link_data(self, dbsrc, cols=None, **kw): 

8613 r"""Save one or more cols from another database 

8614 

8615 :Call: 

8616 >>> db.link_data(dbsrc, cols=None) 

8617 :Inputs: 

8618 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8619 Data container 

8620 *dbsrc*: :class:`dict` 

8621 Additional data container, not required to be a datakit 

8622 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8623 List of columns to link (or *dbsrc.cols*) 

8624 *append*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

8625 Option to append data (or replace it) 

8626 *prefix*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

8627 Prefix applied to *dbsrc* col when saved in *db* 

8628 *suffix*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

8629 Prefix applied to *dbsrc* col when saved in *db* 

8630 :Effects: 

8631 *db.cols*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

8632 Appends each *col* in *cols* where not present 

8633 *db[col]*: *dbsrc[col]* 

8634 Reference to *dbsrc* data for each *col* 

8635 :Versions: 

8636 * 2019-12-06 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8637 * 2021-09-10 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.1; *prefix* and *suffix* 

8638 """ 

8639 # Check type of data set 

8640 if not isinstance(dbsrc, dict): 

8641 # Source must be a dictionary 

8642 raise TypeError("Source data must be a dict") 

8643 # Default columns 

8644 if cols is None: 

8645 # Check for explicit list 

8646 if "cols" in dbsrc.__dict__: 

8647 # Explicit list 

8648 cols = dbsrc.cols 

8649 else: 

8650 # Get all keys 

8651 cols = list(dbsrc.keys()) 

8652 # Check type of *cols* 

8653 if not isinstance(cols, list): 

8654 # Column list must be a list 

8655 raise TypeError( 

8656 "Column list must be a list, got '%s'" 

8657 % cols.__class__.__name__) 

8658 # Append option 

8659 append = kw.get("append", False) 

8660 # Prefix/suffix 

8661 prefix = kw.get("prefix") 

8662 suffix = kw.get("suffix") 

8663 # Loop through columns 

8664 for col in cols: 

8665 # Check type 

8666 if not typeutils.isstr(col): 

8667 raise TypeError("Column names must be strings") 

8668 # Check if data is present 

8669 if col not in dbsrc: 

8670 raise KeyError("No column '%s'" % col) 

8671 # Candidate data 

8672 v = dbsrc[col] 

8673 # Add prefix and suffix to output column (col in *self*) 

8674 if prefix: 

8675 col1 = prefix + col 

8676 else: 

8677 col1 = col 

8678 if suffix: 

8679 col1 = col1 + suffix 

8680 # Get data to save 

8681 if append and col1 in self: 

8682 # Get current values 

8683 v0 = self[col1] 

8684 # Check consistent types and combine values 

8685 if ( 

8686 isinstance(v, float) 

8687 and isinstance(v0, np.ndarray) and v0.ndim == 1 

8688 ): 

8689 # Special case of mismatching types 

8690 v = np.append(v0, v) 

8691 elif not (isinstance(v0, type(v)) or isinstance(v, type(v0))): 

8692 # No way to combine 

8693 sys.stderr.write( 

8694 "Cannot combine old and new values for col '%s'\n" 

8695 % col) 

8696 sys.stderr.flush() 

8697 elif isinstance(v, list): 

8698 # Combine lists 

8699 v = v0 + v 

8700 elif isinstance(v, float): 

8701 # Make an array 

8702 v = np.array([v0, v]) 

8703 elif isinstance(v, np.ndarray): 

8704 # Check dimensions 

8705 if v0.ndim == 1 and v.ndim == 0: 

8706 # Append scalar 

8707 v = np.append(v0, v) 

8708 elif v0.ndim != v.ndim: 

8709 # Mismatching sizes 

8710 sys.stderr.write( 

8711 "Cannot combine %iD and %iD arrays for '%s'\n" 

8712 % (v0.ndim, v.ndim, col)) 

8713 sys.stderr.flush() 

8714 elif v0.ndim == 1: 

8715 # Stack 

8716 v = np.hstack((v0, v)) 

8717 elif v0.ndim == 2: 

8718 # Stack vertically 

8719 v = np.vstack((v0, v)) 

8720 else: 

8721 # No way to combine 3D matrices 

8722 sys.stderr.write( 

8723 "Cannot combine %iD arrays for '%s'\n" 

8724 % (v.ndim, col)) 

8725 sys.stderr.flush() 

8726 else: 

8727 # No general fallback combination 

8728 sys.stderr.write( 

8729 "Cannot combine old and new values for col '%s'\n" 

8730 % col) 

8731 sys.stderr.flush() 

8732 # Save the data 

8733 self.save_col(col1, v) 

8734 

8735 # --- Access --- 

8736 # Look up a generic key 

8737 def get_col(self, k=None, defnames=[], **kw): 

8738 r"""Process a key name, using an ordered list of defaults 

8739 

8740 :Call: 

8741 >>> col = db.get_key(k=None, defnames=[], **kw) 

8742 :Inputs: 

8743 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8744 Data container 

8745 *k*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

8746 User-specified col name; if ``None``, automatic value 

8747 *defnamess*: :class:`list` 

8748 List of applicable default names for the col 

8749 *title*: {``"lookup"``} | :class:`str` 

8750 Key title to use in any error messages 

8751 *error*: {``True``} | ``False`` 

8752 Raise an exception if no col is found 

8753 :Outputs: 

8754 *col*: *k* | *defnamess[0]* | *defnamess[1]* | ... 

8755 Name of lookup key in *db.cols* 

8756 :Versions: 

8757 * 2018-06-22 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8758 """ 

8759 # Get default 

8760 if (k is not None): 

8761 # Check if it's present 

8762 if k not in self.cols: 

8763 # Error option 

8764 if kw.get("error", True): 

8765 # Get title for error message, e.g. "angle of attack" 

8766 ttl = kw.get("title", "lookup") 

8767 # Error message 

8768 raise KeyError("No %s key found" % ttl) 

8769 else: 

8770 # If no error, return ``None`` 

8771 return defnames[0] 

8772 # Otherwise, done 

8773 return k 

8774 # Check list 

8775 if not isinstance(defnames, list): 

8776 raise TypeError("Default col names must be list") 

8777 # Loop through defaults 

8778 for col in defnames: 

8779 # Check if it's present 

8780 if col in self.cols: 

8781 return col 

8782 # If this point is reached, no default found 

8783 if not kw.get("error", True): 

8784 # No error, as specified by user 

8785 return defnames[0] 

8786 # Get title for error message, e.g. "angle of attack" 

8787 ttl = kw.get("title", "lookup") 

8788 # Error message 

8789 raise KeyError("No %s key found" % ttl) 

8790 

8791 # --- Independent Key Values --- 

8792 # Get the value of an independent variable if possible 

8793 def get_xvals(self, col, I=None, **kw): 

8794 r"""Get values of specified column, which may need conversion 

8795 

8796 This function can be used to calculate independent variables 

8797 (*xvars*) that are derived from extant data columns. For 

8798 example if columns *alpha* and *beta* (for angle of attack and 

8799 angle of sideslip, respectively) are present and the user wants 

8800 to get the total angle of attack *aoap*, this function will 

8801 attempt to use ``db.response_arg_converters["aoap"]`` to convert 

8802 available *alpha* and *beta* data. 

8803 

8804 :Call: 

8805 >>> V = db.get_xvals(col, I=None, **kw) 

8806 :Inputs: 

8807 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8808 Database with scalar output functions 

8809 *col*: :class:`str` 

8810 Name of column to access 

8811 *I*: ``None`` | :class:`np.ndarray` | :class:`int` 

8812 Subset indices or single index 

8813 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

8814 Dictionary of values in place of *db* (e.g. *kw[col]* 

8815 instead of *db[col]*) 

8816 *IndexKW*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

8817 Option to use *kw[col][I]* instead of just *kw[col]* 

8818 :Outputs: 

8819 *V*: :class:`np.ndarray` | :class:`float` 

8820 Array of values or scalar for column *col* 

8821 :Versions: 

8822 * 2019-03-12 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8823 * 2019-12-26 ``@ddalle``: From :mod:`tnakit.db.db1` 

8824 """ 

8825 # Option for processing keywrods 

8826 qkw = kw.pop("IndexKW", False) 

8827 # Check for direct membership 

8828 if col in kw: 

8829 # Get values from inputs 

8830 V = kw[col] 

8831 # Checking for quick output 

8832 if not qkw: 

8833 return V 

8834 elif col in self: 

8835 # Get all values from column 

8836 V = self[col] 

8837 else: 

8838 # Get converter 

8839 f = self.get_response_arg_converter(col) 

8840 # Check for converter 

8841 if f is None: 

8842 raise ValueError("No converter for col '%s'" % col) 

8843 elif not callable(f): 

8844 raise TypeError("Converter for col '%s' not callable" % col) 

8845 # Create a dictionary of values 

8846 X = dict(self, **kw) 

8847 # Attempt to convert 

8848 try: 

8849 # Use entire dictionary as inputs 

8850 V = f(**X) 

8851 except Exception: 

8852 raise ValueError("Conversion function for '%s' failed" % col) 

8853 # Check for indexing 

8854 if I is None: 

8855 # No subset 

8856 return V 

8857 elif typeutils.isarray(V): 

8858 # Apply subset 

8859 return V[I] 

8860 else: 

8861 # Not subsettable 

8862 return V 

8863 

8864 # Get independent variable from eval inputs 

8865 def get_xvals_eval(self, k, *a, **kw): 

8866 r"""Return values of a column from inputs to :func:`__call__` 

8867 

8868 For example, this can be used to derive the total angle of 

8869 attack from inputs to an evaluation call to *CN* when it is a 

8870 function of *mach*, *alpha*, and *beta*. This method attempts 

8871 to use :func:`db.response_arg_converters`. 

8872 

8873 :Call: 

8874 >>> V = db.get_xvals_eval(k, *a, **kw) 

8875 >>> V = db.get_xvals_eval(k, coeff, x1, x2, ..., k3=x3) 

8876 :Inputs: 

8877 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8878 Database with scalar output functions 

8879 *k*: :class:`str` 

8880 Name of key to calculate 

8881 *col*: :class:`str` 

8882 Name of output data column 

8883 *x1*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

8884 Value(s) of first argument 

8885 *x2*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

8886 Value(s) of second argument, if applicable 

8887 *k3*: :class:`str` 

8888 Name of third argument or optional variant 

8889 *x3*: :class:`float` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

8890 Value(s) of argument *k3*, if applicable 

8891 :Outputs: 

8892 *V*: :class:`np.ndarray` 

8893 Values of key *k* from conditions in *a* and *kw* 

8894 :Versions: 

8895 * 2019-03-12 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8896 * 2019-12-26 ``@ddalle``: From :mod:`tnakit` 

8897 """ 

8898 # Process coefficient 

8899 X = self.get_arg_value_dict(*a, **kw) 

8900 # Check if key is present 

8901 if k in X: 

8902 # Return values 

8903 return X[k] 

8904 else: 

8905 # Get dictionary of converters 

8906 converters = getattr(self, "response_arg_converters", {}) 

8907 # Check for membership 

8908 if k not in converters: 

8909 raise ValueError( 

8910 "Could not interpret xvar '%s'" % k) 

8911 # Get converter 

8912 f = converters[k] 

8913 # Check class 

8914 if not callable(f): 

8915 raise TypeError("Converter for '%s' is not callable" % k) 

8916 # Attempt to convert 

8917 try: 

8918 # Use entire dictionary as inputs 

8919 V = f(**X) 

8920 except Exception: 

8921 raise ValueError("Conversion function for '%s' failed" % k) 

8922 # Output 

8923 return V 

8924 

8925 # --- Dependent Key Values --- 

8926 # Get exact values 

8927 def get_yvals_exact(self, col, I=None, **kw): 

8928 r"""Get exact values of a data column 

8929 

8930 :Call: 

8931 >>> V = db.get_yvals_exact(col, I=None, **kw) 

8932 :Inputs: 

8933 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8934 Database with scalar output functions 

8935 *col*: :class:`str` 

8936 Name of column to access 

8937 *I*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

8938 Database indices 

8939 :Versions: 

8940 * 2019-03-13 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8941 * 2019-12-26 ``@ddalle``: From :mod:`tnakit` 

8942 """ 

8943 # Check for direct membership 

8944 if col in self: 

8945 # Get all values from column 

8946 V = self[col] 

8947 # Check for indexing 

8948 if I is None: 

8949 # No subset 

8950 return V 

8951 else: 

8952 # Apply subset 

8953 return V[I] 

8954 else: 

8955 # Get evaluation type 

8956 meth = self.get_response_method(col) 

8957 # Only allow "function" type 

8958 if meth != "function": 

8959 raise ValueError( 

8960 ("Cannot evaluate exact values for '%s', " % col) + 

8961 ("which has method '%s'" % meth)) 

8962 # Get args 

8963 args = self.get_response_args(col) 

8964 # Create inputs 

8965 a = tuple([self.get_xvals(k, I, **kw) for k in args]) 

8966 # Evaluate 

8967 V = self.__call__(col, *a) 

8968 # Output 

8969 return V 

8970 

8971 # --- Subsets --- 

8972 # Attempt to get all values of an argument 

8973 def get_all_values(self, col): 

8974 r"""Attempt to get all values of a specified argument 

8975 

8976 This will use *db.response_arg_converters* if possible. 

8977 

8978 :Call: 

8979 >>> V = db.get_all_values(col) 

8980 :Inputs: 

8981 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

8982 Database with scalar output functions 

8983 *col*: :class:`str` 

8984 Name of data column 

8985 :Outputs: 

8986 *V*: ``None`` | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

8987 *db[col]* if available, otherwise an attempt to apply 

8988 *db.response_arg_converters[col]* 

8989 :Versions: 

8990 * 2019-03-11 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

8991 * 2019-12-18 ``@ddalle``: Ported from :mod:`tnakit` 

8992 """ 

8993 # Check if present 

8994 if col in self: 

8995 # Get values 

8996 return self[col] 

8997 # Otherwise check for evaluation argument 

8998 arg_converters = self.__dict__.get("response_arg_converters", {}) 

8999 # Check if there's a converter 

9000 if col not in arg_converters: 

9001 return None 

9002 # Get converter 

9003 f = arg_converters.get(col) 

9004 # Check if there's a converter 

9005 if f is None: 

9006 # No converter 

9007 return 

9008 elif not callable(f): 

9009 # Not callable 

9010 raise TypeError("Converter for col '%s' is not callable" % col) 

9011 # Attempt to apply it 

9012 try: 

9013 # Call in keyword-only mode 

9014 V = f(**self) 

9015 # Return values 

9016 return V 

9017 except Exception: 

9018 # Failed 

9019 return None 

9020 

9021 # Attempt to get values of an argument or column, with mask 

9022 def get_values(self, col, mask=None): 

9023 r"""Attempt to get all or some values of a specified column 

9024 

9025 This will use *db.response_arg_converters* if possible. 

9026 

9027 :Call: 

9028 >>> V = db.get_values(col) 

9029 >>> V = db.get_values(col, mask=None) 

9030 >>> V = db.get_values(col, mask_index) 

9031 :Inputs: 

9032 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9033 Database with scalar output functions 

9034 *col*: :class:`str` 

9035 Name of evaluation argument 

9036 *I*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int` | :class:`bool`] 

9037 Optional subset of *db* indices to access 

9038 :Outputs: 

9039 *V*: ``None`` | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`float`] 

9040 *db[col]* if available, otherwise an attempt to apply 

9041 *db.response_arg_converters[col]* 

9042 :Versions: 

9043 * 2020-02-21 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9044 """ 

9045 # Get all values 

9046 V = self.get_all_values(col) 

9047 # Check for empty result 

9048 if V is None: 

9049 return 

9050 # Check for mask 

9051 if mask is None: 

9052 # No mask 

9053 return V 

9054 # Otherwise check validity of mask 

9055 I = self.prep_mask(mask, V=V) 

9056 # Dimension 

9057 if isinstance(V, list): 

9058 # Index directly 

9059 # (Lists always 1D) 

9060 if I.ndim == 0: 

9061 # Scalar mask 

9062 return V[I] 

9063 elif len(I) > 0 and isinstance(I[0], bool): 

9064 # Apply boolean mask 

9065 return [v for i, v in enumerate(V) if mask[i]] 

9066 else: 

9067 # Apply index mask 

9068 return [V[i] for i in I] 

9069 # Get array dimension 

9070 ndim = V.ndim 

9071 # Create slice that looks up last column 

9072 J = tuple(slice(None) for j in range(ndim-1)) + (I,) 

9073 # Apply mask to last dimension 

9074 return V.__getitem__(J) 

9075 

9076 # Apply a mask to all columns 

9077 def apply_mask(self, mask, cols=None): 

9078 r"""Apply a mask to one or more *cols* 

9079 

9080 :Call: 

9081 >>> db.apply_mask(mask, cols=None) 

9082 >>> db.apply_mask(mask_index, cols=None) 

9083 :Inputs: 

9084 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9085 Database with scalar output functions 

9086 *mask*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool`] 

9087 Logical mask of ``True`` / ``False`` values 

9088 *mask_index*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9089 Indices of values to consider 

9090 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

9091 List of columns to subset (default is all) 

9092 :Effects: 

9093 *db[col]*: :class:`list` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

9094 Subset *db[col][mask]* or similar 

9095 :Versions: 

9096 * 2021-09-10 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9097 """ 

9098 # Default list of columns 

9099 if cols is None: 

9100 cols = self.cols 

9101 # Loop through columns 

9102 for col in cols: 

9103 # Check validity of mask 

9104 if not self.check_mask(mask, col): 

9105 # Skip this column 

9106 continue 

9107 # Get values according to *mask* 

9108 v = self.get_values(col, mask) 

9109 # Save subsetted values 

9110 self[col] = v 

9111 

9112 # Apply a mask to all columns 

9113 def remove_mask(self, mask, cols=None): 

9114 r"""Remove cases in a mask for one or more *cols* 

9115 

9116 This function is the opposite of :func:`apply_mask` 

9117 

9118 :Call: 

9119 >>> db.remove_mask(mask, cols=None) 

9120 >>> db.remove_mask(mask_index, cols=None) 

9121 :Inputs: 

9122 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9123 Database with scalar output functions 

9124 *mask*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool`] 

9125 Logical mask of ``True`` / ``False`` values 

9126 *mask_index*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9127 Indices of values to delete 

9128 *cols*: {``None``} | :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

9129 List of columns to subset (default is all) 

9130 :Effects: 

9131 *db[col]*: :class:`list` | :class:`np.ndarray` 

9132 Subset *db[col][mask]* or similar 

9133 :Versions: 

9134 * 2021-09-10 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9135 """ 

9136 # Check for null action 

9137 if mask is None: 

9138 return 

9139 if len(mask) == 0: 

9140 return 

9141 if not np.any(mask): 

9142 return 

9143 # Default list of columns 

9144 if cols is None: 

9145 cols = self.cols 

9146 # Get size of first *col* 

9147 n = len(self[cols[0]]) 

9148 # Create mask of what to *keep* 

9149 pmask = np.full(n, True) 

9150 # Cases to remove 

9151 pmask[mask] = False 

9152 # Apply tyat 

9153 self.apply_mask(pmask ,cols) 

9154 

9155 # --- Mask --- 

9156 # Prepare mask 

9157 def prep_mask(self, mask, col=None, V=None): 

9158 r"""Prepare logical or index mask 

9159 

9160 :Call: 

9161 >>> I = db.prep_mask(mask, col=None, V=None) 

9162 >>> I = db.prep_mask(mask_index, col=None, V=None) 

9163 :Inputs: 

9164 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9165 Data container 

9166 *mask*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool`] 

9167 Logical mask of ``True`` / ``False`` values 

9168 *mask_index*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9169 Indices of *db[col]* to consider 

9170 *col*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

9171 Reference column to use for size checks 

9172 *V*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

9173 Array of values to test shape/values of *mask* 

9174 :Outputs: 

9175 *I*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9176 Indices of *db[col]* to consider 

9177 :Versions: 

9178 * 2020-03-09 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9179 """ 

9180 # Get data so size can be determined 

9181 if V is None: 

9182 # Check for column 

9183 if col is None: 

9184 raise ValueError("Either column or array must be specified") 

9185 # Get all values 

9186 V = self.get_all_values(col) 

9187 # Assert validity of mask 

9188 self.assert_mask(mask, V=V) 

9189 # Length of reference array 

9190 if isinstance(V, list): 

9191 # Just use length for lists 

9192 n0 = len(V) 

9193 else: 

9194 # Use last dimension 

9195 n0 = V.shape[-1] 

9196 # Ensure array 

9197 if isinstance(mask, (list, int)): 

9198 mask = np.array(mask) 

9199 # Get data type 

9200 if mask is not None: 

9201 dtype = mask.dtype.name 

9202 # Filter mask 

9203 if mask is None: 

9204 # Create indices 

9205 mask_index = np.arange(n0) 

9206 elif dtype.startswith("bool"): 

9207 # Get indices 

9208 mask_index = np.where(mask)[0] 

9209 elif dtype.startswith("int") or dtype.startswith("uint"): 

9210 # Already indices 

9211 mask_index = mask 

9212 else: 

9213 # Bad type 

9214 # Note: should not be reachable 

9215 raise TypeError("Mask must have dtype 'bool' or 'int'") 

9216 # Output 

9217 return mask_index 

9218 

9219 # Check if mask 

9220 def check_mask(self, mask, col=None, V=None): 

9221 r"""Check if *mask* is a valid index/bool mask 

9222 

9223 :Call: 

9224 >>> q = db.check_mask(mask, col=None, V=None) 

9225 >>> q = db.check_mask(mask_index, col=None, V=None) 

9226 :Inputs: 

9227 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9228 Database with scalar output functions 

9229 *mask*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool`] 

9230 Logical mask of ``True`` / ``False`` values 

9231 *mask_index*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9232 Indices of values to consider 

9233 *col*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

9234 Column name to use to create default *V* 

9235 *V*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

9236 Array of values to test shape/values of *mask* 

9237 :Outputs: 

9238 *q*: ``True`` | ``False`` 

9239 Whether or not *mask* is a valid mask 

9240 :Versions: 

9241 * 2020-04-21 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9242 """ 

9243 # Check for empty mask 

9244 if mask is None: 

9245 return True 

9246 # Get values 

9247 if (V is None) and (col is not None): 

9248 # Use all values 

9249 V = self.get_all_values(col) 

9250 # Convert list to array 

9251 if isinstance(mask, (list, int)): 

9252 # Create an array instead of a list 

9253 mask = np.array(mask) 

9254 # Check mask type and dimension 

9255 if not isinstance(mask, np.ndarray): 

9256 # Must be array 

9257 return False 

9258 elif mask.ndim > 1: 

9259 # Bad dimension 

9260 return False 

9261 elif mask.size == 0: 

9262 # Empty mask (``None`` is correct empty mask) 

9263 return False 

9264 # Check dimensions 

9265 if V is not None: 

9266 # Get size 

9267 if isinstance(V, list): 

9268 # Special case for list of strings 

9269 n = len(V) 

9270 else: 

9271 # Use last dimension 

9272 n = V.shape[-1] 

9273 # Get data type 

9274 dtype = mask.dtype.name 

9275 # Check data type 

9276 if dtype.startswith("uint") or dtype.startswith("int"): 

9277 # Check values 

9278 if V is not None: 

9279 # Check values 

9280 if np.min(mask) < -n: 

9281 return False 

9282 elif np.max(mask) >= n: 

9283 return False 

9284 # Ints are valid masks 

9285 return True 

9286 elif dtype.startswith("bool"): 

9287 # Check size 

9288 if V is not None: 

9289 # Check length 

9290 if mask.size != n: 

9291 return False 

9292 # Boolean masks are valid if dimension matches 

9293 return True 

9294 else: 

9295 # Invalid data type 

9296 return False 

9297 

9298 # Ensure mask 

9299 def assert_mask(self, mask, col=None, V=None): 

9300 r"""Make sure that *mask* is a valid index/bool mask 

9301 

9302 :Call: 

9303 >>> db.assert_mask(mask, col=None, V=None) 

9304 >>> db.assert_mask(mask_index, col=None, V=None) 

9305 :Inputs: 

9306 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9307 Database with scalar output functions 

9308 *mask*: ``None`` | :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool`] 

9309 Logical mask of ``True`` / ``False`` values 

9310 *mask_index*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9311 Indices of values to consider 

9312 *col*: {``None``} | :class:`str` 

9313 Column name to use to create default *V* 

9314 *V*: {``None``} | :class:`np.ndarray` 

9315 Array of values to test shape/values of *mask* 

9316 :Versions: 

9317 * 2020-04-21 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9318 """ 

9319 # Check for empty mask 

9320 if mask is None: 

9321 return 

9322 # Get values 

9323 if (V is None) and (col is not None): 

9324 # Use all values 

9325 V = self.get_all_values(col) 

9326 # Convert list to array 

9327 if isinstance(mask, (list, int, np.int32, np.int64)): 

9328 # Create an array instead of a list 

9329 mask = np.array(mask) 

9330 # Check mask type and dimension 

9331 if not isinstance(mask, np.ndarray): 

9332 # Must be array 

9333 raise TypeError("Index mask must be NumPy array") 

9334 elif mask.ndim > 1: 

9335 # Bad dimension 

9336 raise IndexError( 

9337 "%iD index mask; must be scalar or 1D array" % mask.ndim) 

9338 elif mask.size == 0: 

9339 # Empty mask (``None`` is correct empty mask) 

9340 raise ValueError("Index mask must not be empty") 

9341 # Check dimensions 

9342 if V is not None: 

9343 # Get size 

9344 if isinstance(V, list): 

9345 # Special case for list of strings 

9346 n = len(V) 

9347 else: 

9348 # Use last dimension 

9349 n = V.shape[-1] 

9350 # Get data type 

9351 dtype = mask.dtype.name 

9352 # Check data type 

9353 if dtype.startswith("uint") or dtype.startswith("int"): 

9354 # Check values 

9355 if V is not None: 

9356 # Check values 

9357 if np.min(mask) < -n: 

9358 raise ValueError( 

9359 "Index %i is outside of range for array of length %i" 

9360 % (np.min(mask), n)) 

9361 elif np.max(mask) >= n: 

9362 raise ValueError( 

9363 "Index %i is outside of range for array of length %i" 

9364 % (np.max(mask), n)) 

9365 elif dtype.startswith("bool"): 

9366 # Check size 

9367 if V is not None: 

9368 # Check length 

9369 if mask.size != n: 

9370 raise ValueError( 

9371 "Boolean mask (%i) and array (%i) have different sizes" 

9372 % (mask.size, n)) 

9373 else: 

9374 # Invalid data type 

9375 raise TypeError("Invalid mask data type '%s'" % dtype) 

9376 

9377 # --- Sweeps --- 

9378 # Divide into sweeps 

9379 def genr8_sweeps(self, args, **kw): 

9380 r"""Divide data into sweeps with constant values of some *cols* 

9381 

9382 :Call: 

9383 >>> sweeps = db.genr8_sweeps(args, **kw) 

9384 :Inputs: 

9385 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9386 Data container 

9387 *args*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

9388 List of columns names to match 

9389 *mask*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool` | :class:`int`] 

9390 Subset of *db* to consider 

9391 *tol*: {``1e-4``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

9392 Default tolerance for all *args* 

9393 *tols*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict`\ [:class:`float` >= 0] 

9394 Dictionary of tolerances specific to arguments 

9395 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

9396 Additional values to use during evaluation 

9397 :Outputs: 

9398 *sweeps*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`np.ndarray`] 

9399 Indices of entries with constant (within *tol*) values 

9400 of each *arg* 

9401 :Versions: 

9402 * 2020-05-06 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9403 """ 

9404 # --- Column Lists --- 

9405 # Check arg list 

9406 if not isinstance(args, list): 

9407 raise TypeError( 

9408 "Invalid type '%s' for args, must be 'list'" % type(args)) 

9409 elif len(args) < 1: 

9410 raise ValueError("Arg list is empty") 

9411 # Check types of *args* entries 

9412 for j, arg in enumerate(args): 

9413 # Make sure it's a string 

9414 if not typeutils.isstr(arg): 

9415 raise TypeError( 

9416 "Arg %i has invalid type '%s', must be 'str'" 

9417 % (j, type(arg))) 

9418 # --- Options --- 

9419 # Tolerances 

9420 tol = kw.pop("tol", 1e-8) 

9421 tols = kw.pop("tols", {}) 

9422 # --- Mask Prep --- 

9423 # Initialize sweeps 

9424 mask = kw.pop("mask", kw.pop("I", None)) 

9425 # Translate into indices 

9426 mask_index = self.prep_mask(mask, args[0]) 

9427 # --- Search --- 

9428 # Initialize sweeps [array[int]] 

9429 sweeps_parent = [mask_index] 

9430 # Loop through args 

9431 for k, arg in enumerate(args): 

9432 # Get tolerance 

9433 ktol = tols.get(arg, tol) 

9434 # Initialize new sweeps 

9435 sweeps = [] 

9436 # Options to :func:`find` 

9437 kw_k = dict(tol=ktol, mapped=True, **kw) 

9438 # Loop through sweeps from previous level 

9439 for j, J in enumerate(sweeps_parent): 

9440 # Get unique values for this arg (within tolerance) 

9441 V = self.genr8_bkpts(arg, nmin=0, mask=J, tol=ktol) 

9442 # Divide into sweeps 

9443 sweeps_j, _ = self.find([arg], V, mask=J, **kw_k) 

9444 # Save these sweeps 

9445 sweeps.extend(sweeps_j) 

9446 # Save current sweeps 

9447 sweeps_parent = sweeps 

9448 # Output 

9449 return sweeps 

9450 

9451 # --- Search --- 

9452 # Find matches 

9453 def find(self, args, *a, **kw): 

9454 r"""Find cases that match a condition [within a tolerance] 

9455 

9456 :Call: 

9457 >>> I, J = db.find(args, *a, **kw) 

9458 >>> Imap, J = db.find(args, *a, **kw) 

9459 :Inputs: 

9460 *db*: :class:`DataKit` 

9461 Data container 

9462 *args*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`str`] 

9463 List of columns names to match 

9464 *a*: :class:`tuple`\ [:class:`float`] 

9465 Values of the arguments 

9466 *mask*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`bool` | :class:`int`] 

9467 Subset of *db* to consider 

9468 *tol*: {``1e-4``} | :class:`float` >= 0 

9469 Default tolerance for all *args* 

9470 *tols*: {``{}``} | :class:`dict`\ [:class:`float` >= 0] 

9471 Dictionary of tolerances specific to arguments 

9472 *once*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

9473 Option to find max of one *db* index per test point 

9474 *mapped*: ``True`` | {``False``} 

9475 Option to switch output to *Imap* (overrides *once*) 

9476 *kw*: :class:`dict` 

9477 Additional values to use during evaluation 

9478 :Outputs: 

9479 *I*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9480 Indices of cases in *db* that match conditions 

9481 *J*: :class:`np.ndarray`\ [:class:`int`] 

9482 Indices of (*a*, *kw*) that have a match in *db* 

9483 *Imap*: :class:`list`\ [:class:`np.ndarray`] 

9484 List of *db* indices for each test point in *J* 

9485 :Versions: 

9486 * 2019-03-11 ``@ddalle``: Version 1.0 

9487 * 2019-12-26 ``@ddalle``: From :func:`DBCoeff.FindMatches` 

9488 * 2020-02-20 ``@ddalle``: Added *mask*, *once* kwargs 

9489 """ 

9490 # --- Input Checks --- 

9491 # Find a valid argument 

9492 for arg in args: 

9493 # Attempt to either access or convert it 

9494 V = self.get_all_values(arg) 

9495 # Check if it was processed 

9496 if V is not None: 

9497 # Found at least one valid argument 

9498 break 

9499 else: 

9500 # Loop completed; nothing found 

9501 raise ValueError( 

9502 "Cannot find matches for argument list %s" % args) 

9503 # Mask 

9504 mask = kw.pop("mask", None) 

9505 # Overall tolerance default 

9506 tol = kw.pop("tol", 1e-4) 

9507 # Specific tolerances 

9508 tols = kw.pop("tols", {}) 

9509 # Option for unique matches 

9510 once = kw.pop("once", False) 

9511 # Option for mapped matches 

9512 mapped = kw.pop("mapped", False) 

9513 # Number of values 

9514 n0 = len(V) 

9515 # --- Mask Prep --- 

9516 # Get mask 

9517 mask_index = self.prep_mask(mask, arg) 

9518 # Update test size 

9519 n = mask_index.size 

9520 # --- Argument values --- 

9521 # Initialize lookup point 

9522 x = [] 

9523 # Loop through arguments 

9524 for i, col in enumerate(args): 

9525 # Get value 

9526 xi = self.get_arg_value(i, col, *a, **kw) 

9527 # Save it 

9528 x.append(np.asarray(xi)) 

9529 # Normalize arguments 

9530 X, dims = self.normalize_args(x, True) 

9531 # Number of test points 

9532 nx = np.prod(dims) 

9533 # --- Checks --- 

9534 # Initialize tests for database indices (set to ``False``) 

9535 MI = np.full(n, False) 

9536 # Initialize tests for input data indices (set to ``False``) 

9537 MJ = np.full(nx, False) 

9538 # Initialize maps if needed 

9539 if mapped: 

9540 Imap = [] 

9541 # Loop through entries 

9542 for i in range(nx): 

9543 # Initialize tests for this point (set to ``True``) 

9544 Mi = np.full(n, True) 

9545 # Loop through arguments 

9546 for j, k in enumerate(args): 

9547 # Get array of database values 

9548 Xk = self.get_all_values(k) 

9549 # Check if present 

9550 if (k is None) or (Xk is None): 

9551 continue 

9552 # Check size 

9553 if len(Xk) != n0: 

9554 raise ValueError( 

9555 ("Parameter '%s' has size %i, " % (k, len(Xk))) + 

9556 ("expecting %i" % n)) 

9557 # Apply mask 

9558 if mask is not None: 

9559 Xk = self.get_values(k, mask) 

9560 # Get input test value 

9561 xi = X[j][i] 

9562 # Get tolerance for this key 

9563 xtol = tols.get(k, tol) 

9564 # Check match/approx 

9565 if isinstance(Xk, list): 

9566 # Convert to array 

9567 Xk = np.asarray(Xk) 

9568 # Check for match 

9569 if Xk.dtype.name.startswith("str"): 

9570 # Exact match for strings 

9571 Mi = np.logical_and(Mi, Xk == xi) 

9572 else: 

9573 # Use a tolerance 

9574 Mi = np.logical_and(Mi, np.abs(Xk-xi) <= xtol) 

9575 # Check if any cases 

9576 found = np.any(Mi) 

9577 # Got to next test point if no match 

9578 if not found: 

9579 # Save status 

9580 MJ[i] = found 

9581 continue 

9582 # Check reporting method 

9583 if mapped: 

9584 # Save test-point status (no uniqueness check) 

9585 MJ[i] = found 

9586 # Find matches 

9587 I = np.where(Mi)[0] 

9588 # Invert mask if needed 

9589 if mask is not None: 

9590 I = mask_index[I] 

9591 # Append to map 

9592 Imap.append(I) 

9593 elif once: 

9594 # Check for uniqueness 

9595 M2 = np.logical_and(np.logical_not(MI), Mi) 

9596 # Check that 

9597 found = np.any(M2) 

9598 # Save status 

9599 MJ[i] = found 

9600 # Exit if not found (match but previously used) 

9601 if not found: 

9602 continue 

9603 # Select first not-previously-used match 

9604 j2 = np.where(M2)[0][0] 

9605 # Save it 

9606 MI[j2] = True 

9607 else: 

9608 # Save test-point status (no uniqueness check) 

9609 MJ[i] = found 

9610 # Combine point constraints (*Mi* multiple matches) 

9611 MI = np.logical_or(MI, Mi) 

9612 # Convert test point status to indices 

9613 J = np.where(MJ)[0]
